content: The Bush tax cuts, enacted in 2001 and 2003, were set to expire at the end of 2010. This included lower rates for long-term capital gains and dividends. Without legislative action, capital gains tax rates would have increased to 20% and dividends would be taxed at ordinary rates. President Obama proposed to retain lower rates for middle-income taxpayers but increase rates for higher-income earners. The tax rates were extended until the end of 2012. The tax rates for capital gains and dividends were temporarily extended through 2012, with higher rates for married couples earning over $250,000 and singles over $200,000. In 2013, higher-income individuals were taxed at even higher rates, with thresholds set at $480,050 for couples and $453,350 for singles in 2018. The potential revenue gain from increasing capital gains taxes depends on behavioral responses assumed by the Joint Committee on Taxation and the Department of the Treasury. The Obama Administration estimated in February 2010 that allowing the Bush tax cuts for capital gains to expire would have raised $16 billion of revenue in FY2019. However, based on Congressional Budget Office projections in January 2010, the current effective capital gains tax was 13.3% in 2008 and would have increased to 17.9% in 2019, resulting in a revenue difference of $40 billion.
